title: Cochlear Implantation in Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media with Cholesteatoma
chief_complaint: I have had ear problems since childhood, but my hearing has gotten much worse recently. I can no longer communicate in daily situations, even with my hearing aids.

problem_summary.onset: Childhood onset of CSOM; progressive hearing deterioration.
problem_summary.course: Gradual deterioration from bilateral moderate mixed loss to bilateral profound sensorineural loss.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM), Cleft Lip and Palate (CLP), history of left ear tuberculosis with facial palsy, tympanic membrane perforations.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Heavy reliance on lipreading; fatigue and frustration in communication; unable to use hearing aids effectively by age 36.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To improve communication ability for work and daily life.

history.present_illness: Patient is 30 years old. Hearing has gradually deteriorated. She has a 50% central perforation on the left tympanic membrane.
history.otologic_history: Repaired cleft lip and palate. History of left ear tuberculosis and cortical mastoidectomy at age 6. Right ear myringotomy with grommet insertion recently completed.
history.prior_management: Fitted with bilateral high gain/output hearing aids (Phonak SuperFront PP-C-L 4+).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral severe-to-profound mixed hearing loss. Air-bone gaps present in lower frequencies indicating conductive component overlaying sensorineural loss.

numeric_results.Bone_Conduction: Elevated but better than air thresholds (e.g., Right BC ~20-35 dB HL at 500-1000Hz), confirming mixed nature.

tests.name: Speech Audiometry (Cantonese)
tests.key_findings: Poor speech recognition in auditory-only mode despite high-power hearing aids. Excellent performance when visual cues (lipreading) are added.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Not completed due to persistent conductive pathologies (grommet in right ear, perforation in left ear).

history.present_illness: Patient is now 36 years old. Hearing has deteriorated significantly to profound levels. Bilateral myringoplasty was performed recently to obliterate the CSOM process.
history.functional_impact: Patient is no longer able to communicate in daily situations. Unable to repeat sentences with hearing aids.
history.prior_management: Bilateral myringoplasty performed. Hearing aids no longer provide benefit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Deterioration to bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. No usable hearing in either ear.

tests.name: Speech Audiometry
tests.key_findings: Patient was not able to repeat any sentences with hearing aids at maximum setting in auditory-only mode. Testing in combined mode not performed due to patient fatigue.

numeric_results.Sentence_Recognition_Auditory_Only: 0% (implied by 'not able to repeat any sentences')

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media and cleft lip/palate. Over six years (age 30 to 36), hearing progressed from a severe-to-profound mixed loss to a profound sensorineural hearing loss with no usable residual hearing. Speech perception scores with high-power hearing aids dropped to 0% auditory-only, indicating that conventional amplification is no longer beneficial.
counseling_points: Your hearing has decreased to a level where hearing aids are no longer providing enough benefit for speech understanding.
Cochlear implantation is the recommended option to restore access to sound and improve communication.
Because of your history of chronic ear infections (CSOM), there are specific risks with the surgery, including a higher risk of infection spreading or meningitis.
We must ensure your ear is dry and free of active infection before proceeding with implantation.
Post-surgery, you will need close monitoring to check for any signs of infection or electrode issues.
notes_for_actor: You have dealt with ear infections and surgeries since you were a child.
You are very reliant on lipreading. If the audiologist covers their mouth, you cannot understand them.
By the second visit (age 36), you are frustrated and tired because your hearing aids stopped working for you.
You are motivated to communicate better for your work and daily life.
